Title: IAD: Collab Rsch: Research/Education Infrastructure Based on Modular Miniature Robot Systems

Project Proposed:
This collaborative project, developing a modular hardware and software infrastructure (miniature robots with the pertinent software), aims to identify minimum capabilities required for accomplishing tasks which are crucial for most robotics-sensor applications. The work involves investigating the relationship between the capabilities of individual units and the collective capabilities of the entire robotic team. The major innovation lies in the creation of a flexible design spectrum for both research and education based on the capabilities of the individual units. On the lower end of the spectrum, the basic design "Explorer," a robot based on a Gumstix unit and earlier robot designs from one of the institutions, provides an inexpensive and yet significantly powerful solution. On the higher end, the platform "MicroVision," a robot based on the Intel Pentium M processor and RoboAudioStix board, provides real-time video streaming and processing using standard off-the-shelf hardware and open-source video algorithms. The modularity of both designs allows the addition of special hardware capabilities. The infrastructure aims at low-cost, easy-to-use platforms that support research and can be adopted into courses. Specifically, this development enables design of robotics sensor-network systems that can
. Communicate reliably and efficiently via multi-hop in the presence of frequent network topology changes;
. Identify relative positions among members of a robotic team promptly and accurately for effective coordination;
. Enable energy-efficient marsupial maneuvering;
. Provide collaborative sensing with spatial, temporal, and spatiotemporal coverage guarantees; and
. Interact with environments through grasping and manipulation.

Broader Impacts: This infrastructure will be used for senior theses and K-12 students will be engaged via school visits and science field days. An annual Robot Camp will be held. The activities will be helped by the National Center for Engineering and Technology Education (NCETE). Coordination with Berea and Smith College, as well as UVA ascertains exchange among undergraduate- and minority-serving institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This primary goals of this collaborative project are (1) to develop a modular hardware and  software infrastructure (miniature robots with the pertinent software) and (2) to identify minimum capabilities required for accomplishing tasks which are crucial for most robotic sensor network applications.

Our efforts focused on developing navigation and tracking algorithms for various settings. On the basic research front, we developed algorithms for robots to track people using wireless signals and visual information. We have also developed algorithms for energy efficient navigation. These results formed the basis of a number of publications. In addition to Ph.D.  students, Master's and Undergraduate students were involved in the research. Two of these undergraduates have moved on to become Ph.D. students. Some of the code developed for this  project is available through: http://rsn.cs.umn.edu/index.php/Educational_Robotics

On the education front, we worked closely with collaborators at the Rensselaer Polytechnic  Institute and Smith College which is a 4-year liberal arts college for women. RPI's role in the project was to support the use of new educational robots developed at University of Minnesota.

Smith College was chosen as a dissemination site. In 2010, one of the UMN Ph.D. students, along  with an RPI Master's student visited Smith to deliver three basic robot platform and the  software application programming interface developed at the University of Minnesota (see attached picture). The robots were used for final projects of the  senior-level Robotics seminar at Smith College.

This work was also the basis for a number of outreach activities. See
http://rsn.cs.umn.edu/index.php/Education


The investigators of the project co-organized an educational workshop held at IEEE International Conference on Robotics and Automation in Shanghai China in 2011. The goal of the workshop, entitled, 'Educating Robotics Engineers and Scientists,' was to explore the design of dedicated robotics curricula especially at the undergraduate level. We discussed the state-of-the art in educational platforms, and identified a list of desired qualities
to be incorporated into future platforms. In parallel, we explored
the use of robots for teaching in other disciplines such as real-time
computing, operating systems, and engineering. The workshop web page
is here: http://www-users.cs.umn.edu/~isler/workshop/icra11.html.
